policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation

title.narrative: Locally owned media development initiatives benefit from professional networks and promote mutual understanding

target.value: Networks and exchanges improved to promote mutual understanding

actual.value: In Syria. efforts to coordinate international media development saw important progress. In Tunisia. the programme continued its efforts to ensure that broader media reform processes are led by national stakeholders through the Civil Coalition for the Defence of Freedom of Expression. In Yemen. the conflict resulted in an increased need for coordination across the media community. much of which was in exile.

title.narrative: Institution-building of key professional institutions is on target

Institution-building of key professional institutions (mid-career training institutions, professional associations, specialised centres on documentary film, investigative journalism and selected media outlets) is on target.

actual.value: In Tunisia. the programme provided guidance and financial support to the Tunis Centre for Press Freedom which initiated a process of self-evaluation and strategic reflection with major stakeholders in the media sector. The reflection culminated in a five-year strategy that takes stock of the Centre’s experience and builds on its strengths. while outlining problems and identifying possible solutions. At the other end of the spectrum from Tunisia’s relatively constructive progress. were Yemen. Syria and Egypt. In the case of Yemen. the country’s civil war greatly affected efforts under this component. with IMS’ main partner. the Yemen Journalists’ Syndicate – like most other civil society organisations – forced to cease most of its activities. In Egypt. with a stark increase in state repression. the programme supported with financial means. the Arab Network for Human Rights Information. one of the key human rights and freedom of expression groups operating in the country.

title.narrative: Programme activities to improve professional standards of media outputs in key media are on target and ensure unbiased and accurate representations of both men and women.

actual.value: Elsewhere in Jordan. MCP continued its support in the form of journalistic training to a network of women journalists from the journalism faculty of the local university in the very conservative southern province of Ma’an. A similarly successful aspect of the Media Cooperation Programme is its support to the Khabar Broadcasting Corporation (KBC). a sole private independent TV channel in the otherwise heavily state-dominated media environment of Algeria.

One pocket of media excellence is Nawaat. one of the leading independent collective blog platforms in Tunisia. Established in 2004. it was at the forefront of the struggle against Ben Ali’s regime and it currently plays a critical role in the country’s transition by providing investigative reports and opening the space for opinions and debates. Another partner in the category of innovate online media is 7iber. now one of Jordan’s most advanced multimedia production companies with a strong appeal to a young audience.

title.narrative: An environment conducive to media freedom and safe working conditions for male and female journalists

target.value: An environment conducive to media freedom and safe working conditions for male and female journalists strengthened in countries undergoing transition/ conflict in the MENA region.

actual.value: Overall. this outcome is partly on target. Efforts to further reform processes are only on target in Tunisia. whereas the contexts in Egypt and Yemen deteriorated more than anticipated. leaving little room for progress. In terms of making journalists feel less vulnerable. programmes in Yemen. Syria and Egypt have progressed and are partly on target.

title.narrative: The organizational, technical and financial capacity of media outlets and key institutions has been enhanced
The organizational, technical and financial capacity of media outlets and key institutions has been enhanced

target.value: The organizational. technical and financial capacity of media outlets and key institutions has been enhanced

actual.value: The programme has managed to stay partly on track. Propping up key media institutions is a vital aspect of the programme's work in nearly every country where it operates. The programme saw steady progress with some institutions and less progress with others. Bearing this in mind. the programme moves forward with a keen awareness of specific weaknesses in a volatile regional situation.

title.narrative: Media content that is diverse, meets professional and ethical standards and is guided by the public interest is enhanced
Media content that is diverse, meets professional and ethical standards and is guided by the public interest is enhanced

target.value: Professional standards and diverse content enhanced

actual.value: This outcome is largely speaking on track. even if progress will vary somewhat between the components. The programme's successes underline the importance of working with a variety of both legacy and new media outlets.

title.narrative: Programme activities related to networking and coalition building are on target and address local priorities in terms of gender.

actual.value: In the spring of 2015. IMS invited seven leading female media professionals from the Middle East and North Africa on a road trip through Denmark. The project highlighted the situation of women in the media in the region and sought to establish contact between media professionals engaged in gender issues there and in Denmark. Over five days. the participants travelled by bus from Aarhus over Odense to Copenhagen under the theme “Challenging Male Dominance in the Media”.

Tunisia's Civil Coalition for the Defence of Freedom of Expression is a member-based based advocacy group representing a wide selection of Tunisian media rights organisations. IMS supported the establishment of the Coalition by inviting and funding the participation of international experts and stakeholders. and subsequently engaged in an ongoing dialogue with the Coalition’s stakeholders as they were progressed and drafted their input to the reform process. Since its establishment in 2013. the Coalition. whose work is coordinated by the association Vigilance. has facilitated a series of important debates and formulated critical propositions on legal reforms and the professionalisation of the media sector. contributed to the establishment of the long-awaited Independent High Authority for Audiovisual Communication (HAICA) and provided an important forum for debating the country’s constitution before it was adopted in 2014.
